faqs.question: Who can donate blood?
faqs.answer: Generally, healthy individuals between 18 and 65 years old, weighing at least 50 kg, can donate blood. Some medical conditions and medications may affect eligibility.

faqs.question: How often can I donate blood?
faqs.answer: You can donate whole blood every 3 months (for men) and every 4 months (for women). Plasma and platelet donations may have different intervals.

faqs.question: Is blood donation safe?
faqs.answer: Yes! Blood donation is a safe process. A new, sterile needle is used for each donor and discarded after use.

faqs.question: What should I do before and after donating blood?
faqs.answer: Before donating: Eat a healthy meal, drink plenty of water, and get enough rest. After donating: Rest for a few minutes, drink fluids, and avoid heavy exercise for the rest of the day.

faqs.question: Can I donate if I have a cold or flu?
faqs.answer: No, you must be completely healthy and free from cold, flu, or any infection before donating blood.

faqs.question: Will donating blood make me weak?
faqs.answer: No, your body quickly replenishes the donated blood. You might feel slightly tired, but drinking fluids and eating well will help you recover.
